bibl.title: Letter from R.H. Creel to Henry Rose Carter, April 30, 1923

div1.p: Creel lists vessels sailing between the west coast of South America and Asia.

div1.head: Letter from R.H. Creel to Henry Rose Carter, April 30, 1923
div1.opener:
HWE-
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
SAN FRANCISCO QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
ANGEL ISLAND, CALIF.
April 30th, 1923
Assistant Surgeon-General H.R. Carter
U. S. Public Health Service
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In response to your inquiry of April 18th, I
have investigated and so far as I can ascertain the only
vessels plying between the Asiatic coast and the west
coast of South America, via San Francisco are some four
or five vessels belonging to the Toyo Kishen Kaisha,
namely the ANYO MARU, the GINYO MARU, the SEIYO MARU and
the RAKUYO MARU. They average about 5500-net and 9000-
gross tonnage, carrying both cargo and passengers. This
line makes about ten trips a year with the four vessels
combined, each trip consuming about five months for the
entire voyage, going and coming. Sailing from Hongkong,
these vessels touch at Keelung, Moji, Kobe, Yokohama,
Honolulu, San Francisco, Los Angeles Calleao, Mollendo,
Arica, Iquique, and Valparaiso. The trip from the west
coast to Japan takes about two months.

These are the only vessels sailing from San
Francisco that make the trip back to the Orient by way
of South American ports, but it may be that a number
of other vessels plying directly between South America
and the Asiatic coast or otherwise proceed from Europe
or from the Eastern coast of the United States via the
Canal or around the Horn, touching at Peru or Guayquil
and thence to the Orient. I assume that Dr. Cuello at
Guayquil or Dr. Castro at Callao could give you more def-
inite information on this latter aspect of the subject.
Dr. Sweet also might give you information as to any
vessels proceeding from Mexico or South America to the
Orient by way of Honolulu.

With kind regards to you both, in which Mrs.
Creel joins me,
